channel.title: math.GM updates on arXiv.org
channel.description: math.GM updates on the arXiv.org e-print archive.

item.title: $\sigma$-Sets and $\sigma$-Antisets
item.description: arXiv:2501.00047v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: In this paper we present a brief study of the $\sigma$-set-$\sigma$-antiset duality that occurs in $\sigma$-set theory and we also present the development of the integer space $3^{A}=\left\langle 2^{A}, 2^{A^{-}} \right\rangle$ for the cardinals $|A|=2,3$ together with its algebraic properties. In this article, we also develop a presentation of some of the properties of fusion of $\sigma$-sets and finally we present the development and definition of a type of equations of one $\sigma$-set variable.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Gatica, Alfonso Bustamente

item.title: Notes on the Golden Ratio: The Golden Rule of Vector Similarities in Space
item.description: arXiv:2302.02494v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: In this work, we have abstractly generalized the similarity law for multidimensional vectors. Initially, the law of similarity was derived for one-dimensional vectors. Although it operated with such values of the ratio of parts of the whole, it meant linear dimensions (a line is one-dimensionality). The concept of the general golden ratio (GGR) for the vectors in the multidimensional space is presented and described in detail with equations and solutions. It shown that the GGR depends on the angles. Main properties of the GGR are given with illustrative examples. We introduce and discuss the concept of the similar vectors and the set of similarities for a given vector. Also, we present our vision on the theory of the golden ratio for triangles and describe the similar triangles with examples.
item.dc:creator: Artyom M. Grigoryan, Meruzhan M. Grigoryan

item.title: Derivation of some definite integrals
item.description: arXiv:2412.10395v5 Announce Type: replace Abstract: In this work derivations of definite integrals listed in Prudnikov volume I, Gradshteyn and Ryzhik and a few other tables are produced. Special cases of these integrals in terms of fundamental constants are also evaluated. The method used in these derivations is contour integration.
item.dc:creator: Robert Reynolds
